posts.cooked: Hey, i’ve been attempting to create a PIDLib, a basic file that given a measurement and setpoint, iterates on a PID loop, given any function that moves motors, and then stores the values once the error goes under a certain number. I was wondering if anyone had any input for it, or suggestions for additional functionality? I already know in a basic sense what I’m doing, but any suggestions for extra features would be appreciated.
I guess the question is what are you trying to do with this? What role do you want it to fill? Maybe try and fill gaps not covered by WPILib or vendor libraries.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I see you are making a wrapper for the WPILib PID and not reinventing your own.

A reverse option could be handy. All the motor controllers and many sensors already have that. Wouldn’t hurt to include it for non-motor controller usage.

Including a kS static amount that barely does not make the plant move and follows the sign of the output is useful. I coded essentially the same wrapper this morning and included those two functions. The WPILib feed forward has the kS but it doesn’t follow the sign of the error only.

Your incremental amounts for the gains should be settable variables and default to 0.  They are a couple of orders of magnitude larger than what I was tuning today and would have destroyed the machine.
hmm those are good ideas! how would i implement the backwards thing? and do you think what i have so far would work?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
As far as making adjustable, reusable classes like this, the the Sendable interfaces can really help. It makes adjusting parameters and other internal data very streamlined.

Since the Sendable interface only has one method, writing your own classes that implement Sendable(and thus automatically log values to and/or consume values from the dashboard) is extremely easy: ...

As far as the PID part, it seems like your goal  (or at least your code) is trying to do PID Auto-tuning, which will not be effectively performed by this code. Effectively, the moment the PID crosses the threshhold, this considers it “tuned”. This is unlikely to accurately reflect the performance you want out of a PID . A tuned PID is more than about getting your error to zero, but about maintaining system stability (not oscillating), minimizing overshooting, and maintaining a low error when your system is disturbed.

A perfectly tuned system will respond with a damped response: Immediately recovering from a disturbance in the lowest possible amount of time, without any overshoot beyond the setpoint, and without oscillating/settling. Doing this either requires either a lot of math for system dynamics, a lot of time, or a very, very well developed auto-calibration process.

If you’re using SysID (it’s worth it, trust me) then this actually helps provide these values based on your system’s response to changing motor outputs. Analyzing Data — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

If you want to roll your own tuner, there’s a number of math-heavy white papers, but this might help walk you through the concepts at a more casual level. Arduino PID Autotune Library « Project Blog

link_counts.title: Arduino PID Autotune Library « Project Blog
Analyzing Data — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Writing Your Own Sendable Classes — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
tekdemo:

Doing this either requires either a lot of math for system dynamics, a lot of time, or a very, very well developed auto-calibration process.

Great post overall, but in my experience manual tuning can be very fast provided you have a solid understanding of the system you’re trying to tune and are approaching it with a sound control strategy.

A simple exponential search works remarkably well in practice.

posts.cooked: so you think itd work? cause thats what ive found in my pid tuning, just start with a really small P value and move it up slowly. and the point of this is not to be instant, its to be something that you can leave running, and let it slowly hone in.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I didn’t want to discourage you since I, too, make hacky PID tuning stuff occasionally (but with limited scope and I have my reasons). Working through all this can be a great learning experience.

@Oblarg is right about the usual ease of tuning and I’ll water his response down some by saying the students don’t have to have solid understanding to be successful tuning PID in a few minutes. A brief lecture by me drawing some typical response curves to start them off normally suffices. They know what to expect with their exponential search for values (0.000001, 0.00001, 0.0001, 0.001. , etc) and are ready to hit disable.

The relay method referenced by @tekdemo is effective, clever tuning and works. However, the code referenced, unless recently updated, is buggy. I converted the Arduino version to roboRIO (or was it cRIO?) C++ and then Java. It tunes a system in about 1/4 second. There is a lot of variation so run it 3 or 4 times, eyeball the average, and you have pretty good tuning ready to fine-tune-manually for even better results. GitHub - tom131313/PID-AutoTune-Library: Java version of the Arduino-PID-AutoTune-Library

To answer your question on reverse direction (phase) - to make the output less if the input is more then use a negative sign on the output. This is effectively the setInverse(true) we use on motor controllers.

Why did I bother even looking at the relay tuning scheme and code? Long ago there was not the documentation by the motor controller manufacturers and WPILib on PID control. We were on our own. Now there is adequate description of how-to and even packaged code like the SYSID, Phoenix Tuner X, and Rev client all of which make tuning much easy than the good ole days.

link_counts.title: GitHub - tom131313/PID-AutoTune-Library: Java version of the Arduino-PID-AutoTune-Library

posts.cooked: 1/4 of a second is rlly quick! so do you think i should try to make it more like the code @tekdemo referenced?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I forked the original Arduino library code and debugged it and added a feature or two that I saw others had made in their own forks. Later I made the Java version - essentially identical code; old C++ was the same as old Java.

I don’t use the AutoTuner mostly because the setup of the system is tedious compared to using, for example, the Phoenix tuner. With the Phoenix tuner the students can tune their system faster than writing code to wrap around or insert into their robot code.

Playing with PID tuning can be fun and instructive and start you along learning control theory but if you have limited time is it important compared to other projects you could be doing? Given the good PID tools currently available my team sees learning effective application of PathPlanner and Choreo and maybe chasing game pieces with OpenCV or AI a good use of our time to be more competitive. There is a recent thread about off-season projects and they all sound better to me than fussing with writing PID tools. Learn how to use the PID tuning tools and use them again for troubleshooting system problems during competitions and you will be well-served.

The caveat to my statement of my team priorities is we don’t have time to invent much from scratch. We use COTS resources (almost) as much as possible. For example, it broke my heart a little to buy LImeLight Vision cameras instead of doing our own vision as we had done for years. Our code was better but took too much time that the students were not willing to do at the expense of doing other things. All this can be somewhat cyclic as classes of students pass through and a freshman team ages to more capable seniors and highly depends on if we get one extremely motivated student to do special projects and then what special project do they pick?
yeah, sadly the motors we use dont have a tuner that weve found, and i am the only programmer on my team, so i would prefer to just use a tool if possible

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: What motor controller do you use?
neos with sparkmaxes. do they have a tuning software? and if so, does that tuning software actually like work for full drivetrain motion?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
This helps you Telemetry Tab | REV Hardware Client and for your drivetrain it looks like SysId is the tool to use.

I don’t think you indicated swerve drive or not and what are you using for the PID controller - WPILib, SparkMax internal? Note that the WPILib swerve uses a Profiled Controller for the steer motors which you are not covering in your code. The drive is plain PID .

You don’t show how you terminate your iterative process of searching for gains but I’d bet you need a really long hallway if you are just going to start and wait a while for the tune to end. And you’ll need to be steering the robot while tuning so it doesn’t crash into the side walls.

Sure the Relay method of tuning like was posted will work and there is likely an example or two in my GitHub repository but I’d try other ways of tuning than that. Using a tachometer to verify and the Rev Client with the robot drive wheels in the air will get you close and you can tweak the numbers if you want to but you don’t have to with the robot on the carpet.

this was mainly meant to be for turning PIDs, used with swerve drive. although i ideally could also use it for things like arms. it would always be for things with multiple motors. my idea was to plug the output value into my drive method, and then just let it slowly hone closer and closer into the target angle, similar to what i do manually.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Mateo:

similar to what i do manually

To detect a nearly critically damped steer motor while driving on carpet at various speeds while protecting against mechanism damage your brain  is doing a lot of fine computations by observing the Rev Hardware Client plots (or Phoenix Tuner plots or your own SmartDashboard plots) of wheel position that are hard to duplicate in code and are not yet in your code as far as I can tell.

the method im referring to is literally just: start with a rlly small P value, slowly move it up until the robot moves, and then tune the three constants normally. i dont generally look at the graphs, i just look and see how close our gyro angle is to our target angle and work from there. to clarify, this is for turning the whole robot (or arm) not just individual modules.

so what would you suggest?
